user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_Lock_Global_Impl:
```c
void OS_Lock_Global_Impl(osal_objtype_t idtype)
{
    OS_impl_objtype_lock_t *impl;
    int                     ret;

    impl = OS_impl_objtype_lock_table[idtype];

    if (impl != NULL)
    {
        ret = pthread_mutex_lock(&impl->mutex);
        if (ret != 0)
        {
            OS_DEBUG("pthread_mutex_lock(&impl->mutex): %s", strerror(ret));
        }
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_Lock_Global_Impl:
OS_impl_objtype_lock_t *const OS_impl_objtype_lock_table[OS_OBJECT_TYPE_USER] = {
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_UNDEFINED]   = NULL,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TASK]     = &OS_global_task_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_QUEUE]    = &OS_queue_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_COUNTSEM] = &OS_count_sem_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_BINSEM]   = &OS_bin_sem_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_MUTEX]    = &OS_mutex_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM]   = &OS_stream_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_DIR]      = &OS_dir_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE] = &OS_timebase_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB]   = &OS_timecb_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_MODULE]   = &OS_module_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_FILESYS]  = &OS_filesys_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONSOLE]  = &OS_console_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR]  = &OS_condvar_lock,
}
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t mutex;
    pthread_cond_t  cond;
} OS_impl_objtype_lock_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_objtype_t
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No 'for' statements are present in the provided target function OS_Lock_Global_Impl or in the additional definitions. The code fragments shown consist of: a simple conditional (if), a call to pthread_mutex_lock, an array of designated initializers, typedefs and an empty OS_DEBUG macro — none contain or expand to a for loop in the provided snippets. pthread_mutex_lock/strerror are library calls (not for loops in this code). The table initialization uses designators and does not involve a for statement. Therefore there are no code fragments relevant to MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 (well-formed for loops) to investigate in the supplied code. If there are for-loops in other files or in macros not provided here, those would need to be supplied to allow inspection.
